headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. This is Joyce Brooks, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you for joining today's call for a discussion of McCormick's third quarter financial results and our latest outlook for 2016. To accompany this call, we've posted a set of sli
componenttext:
Good morning. This is Joyce Brooks, Vice President of Investor Relations. Thank you for joining today's call for a discussion of McCormick's third quarter financial results and our latest outlook for 2016. To accompany this call, we've posted a set of slides at ir.mccormick.com. We'll begin with remarks from Lawrence Kurzius, President and CEO and Mike Smith, Executive Vice President and CFO. [Operator Instructions]  During our remarks, we will refer to non-GAAP financial measures. These include adjusted operating income and adjusted earnings per share that exclude the impact of special charges as well as information in constant currency. Reconciliations to the GAAP results are included in this morning's press release and slides. As a reminder, today's presentation contains projections and other forward-looking statements. Actual results could differ materially from those projected. The company undertakes no obligation to update or revise publicly any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or other factors. As seen on Slide 2, our forward-looking statement also provides information on risk factors that could affect our financial results. 
It's now my pleasure to turn the discussion over to Lawrence.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joyce. Good morning, everyone, thanks for joining us. McCormick's third quarter results continued the strong performance we delivered on the first half of 2016 with adjusted earnings per share of $1.03. In constant currency, we grew sales 6% wi
componenttext:
Thank you, Joyce. Good morning, everyone, thanks for joining us. McCormick's third quarter results continued the strong performance we delivered on the first half of 2016 with adjusted earnings per share of $1.03. In constant currency, we grew sales 6% with increases in both segments in each of our 3 regions and grew adjusted operating income 15%. These results demonstrate the effective execution of our strategy designed to drive both top line sales and significant productivity improvements. This balanced approach is being managed by McCormick leaders and employees around the world, and I thank them for their effort and engagement. 
For the year-to-date financial results and momentum heading into the fourth quarter, we're well positioned to deliver record results in 2016. Taking a look at the third quarter, we were pleased with the performance of both our consumer and industrial segments. On a constant currency basis, we grew consumer segment sales 7% and increased adjusted operating income 12%. As those who follow McCormick know, we're driving sales with increases in our base business, new products and acquisitions. All 3 of these drivers contributed to consumer segment sales increase this quarter. 
Our base business growth was particularly strong in the Americas region and led by sales of core McCormick and Lawry's brands spices and seasonings. Also, our sales of recipe mixes, including wet recipe mixes have picked up in the U.S. and we gained category share this quarter. 
China was another major driver of the consumer segment sales increase this quarter with double-digit growth in constant currency and category share gains for both herbs and spices and recipe mixes. 
As for innovation, we shared with you at our June earnings call that agree great lineup products we are launching in the second half of our fiscal year. These include the rollout of Herb Grinders in additional markets, organic recipe mixes and Kitchen Basics bone broth in the U.S., which is a simple way to add flavor and 10 grams of protein per serving. 
Internationally, among the new products we're introducing we're introducing, our new World Cuisine [ph] recipe mixes across Europe and innovative dessert items in France and Australia. 
On the acquisition front, we had an incremental benefit this quarter from both Stubb's and Gourmet Garden. While it is less than 6 months since we acquired Gourmet Garden, I'm pleased to report that we're already gaining new distribution for these products in the U.S. and our first retail placement in Canada. 
While constant currency sales rose 7% for the consumer segment, the increase was even higher for adjusted operating income at 12% in constant currency. Led by our comprehensive of continuous improvement program, CCI, we're making great progress in lowering costs throughout our business and improving margins for both our consumer and industrial segments. We are well on our way toward reaching our goal of $100 million to $110 million cost reductions for 2016. We also had more positive mix this period. This included sales in North America with the strength of our branded business outpacing our sales of economy products and in the Asia/Pacific region where we benefited from our year-ago actions to improve our product mix and margins. 
Turning to our industrial segment on Slide 6, we grew sales 4% and increased adjusted operating income 23% in constant currency. We had solid sales results in each of our 3 regions and Mike will go through some of those specific drivers. 
Our growth strategy to excel in customer intimacy and consumer insights is really paying off for the industrial segment. This is evident in our third quarter growth and share gains of our branded food service sales in the U.S. and other markets and we are meeting consumer demand for organic flavors, non-GMO product and a whole range of on-trend flavors. In this regard, the addition of Brand Aromatics in 2015 has been a real success, expanding our capabilities and leading to new business. Increasingly, our industrial customers are also seeking innovative solutions for healthier food, including snacking, which is also driving higher sales. 
The third quarter profit growth for our industrial segment was particularly high this quarter with adjusted operating income of 23% in constant currency and we increased adjusted operating income margin more than 100 basis points. CCI was a significant driver of this increase and business mix was also a key contributor. 
Our customers are seeking unique flavors that tend to be more complex, value added and higher-margin. We're unlocking some new opportunities, most recently with flavors for savory side dishes and dessert baking mixes with our FlavorCell technology, encapsulated flavors that offer protection and controlled release in a wide variety of processing environments. 
These segment results with the excellent growth in adjusted operating income helped us achieve adjusted earnings per share of $1.03, an $0.18 increase from $0.85 in the third quarter of 2015. The higher operating income added $0.11 of the increase and the other main factor were the lower tax rate, as Mike will describe more fully. 
With one quarter remaining in the fiscal year, we've increased our guidance for adjusted earnings per share to $3.75 to $3.79 from our previous guidance at the upper end of $3.68 to $3.75. This new range is based on our strong third quarter results, partially offset by several headwinds for earnings per share as we move into the fourth quarter. 
The first headwind is a greater impact from unfavorable currency particularly for our joint venture in Mexico. Second, a reduction in our initial 2016 plants for share repurchases due to acquisition activities throughout the year for both completed and uncompleted deal. As many of you know, it's our practice to curtail share repurchases in conjunction with acquisition activity to achieve our target debt leverage. And third, the rising costs for certain raw materials, particularly vanilla and garlic. When we provide the material cost inflation outlook for 2017 in our January earnings call, it like likely to be above 2016's low single-digit rate. As we've done in the past, we expect to manage this increase through pricing actions and cost savings. While we've already begun to take pricing actions, we anticipate some near-term slowdown in our rate of margin improvement. Part of his remarks, Mike will be providing more comments on our outlook. 
Next, let's take a closer look at our growth in our U.S. consumer business beginning on Slide 8. As I indicated, our third quarter sales growth for McCormick and Lawry's brand spices and seasonings in the U.S. was particularly strong. Leading this increase were McCormick spices and herbs. Our conversion to non-GMO labeling has gone extremely well and we activated marketing for new Herb Grinders. We, at McCormick, are proud to share that our Herb Grinders are recently awarded innovation of the year by GMA, the Grocery Manufacturers Association. 
We're continuing to increase our digital marketing to drive sales. Our plans are to take digital marketing to nearly 2/3 of our total U.S. advertising this year, up from 46% in 2015. 
Traffic to our McCormick.com site is up 15% versus last year as millennials and others generation seek recipes, how-to videos and other content. Just lastly, we learned that L2 Research ranked our McCormick brand of the U.S. #5 out of 126 food brands in its annual Digital IQ ranking. For a third year in a row, we've achieved the #5 spot, which places at L2's "Genius Level". The L2 ranking is based on the following criteria: Brand site effectiveness and e-tailer investments, digital marketing, social media based on reach, search and engagement; and mobile, encompassing experience, search, advertising and apps. 
In 2016, we're getting more value out of each marketing dollar. In the U.S. we're on track to reduce our nonworking media by 20% in 2016 versus 2015 and increase our market working media by 12%. Across all markets, we're shifting our marketing towards more high ROI digital marketing. As a result of these actions and including the currency impact, we've lowered our planned increase in brand marketing for 2016 from an increase of $20 million to an increase of $15 million. This is a 6% increase from a brand marketing spend in 2015, and well ahead of our projected 3% year-on-year sales increase on a reported basis.
Also behind the strong sales performance this quarter was our great grilling season. We grew Grill Mates sales 6% with incremental support and the introduction of new single-use marinates, an innovation of that is exceeding our expectations at market. 
Sales of our Lawry's brand seasoned salt and other products were up with some strong brand marketing activity. And as worked through resets of our gourmet line through new organic versions, rose at double-digit rates.
For those of you know who watch the retail consumption data, our reported sales growth might seem at odds with the latest data, which has shown a sequential increase in category share decline for McCormick versus the last quarter. A large part of the share decline of this quarter related to the significant retail shelf disruption from the conversion of our gourmet product line. We remarked on this as part of our outlook at our June earnings call. As the old gourmet products rotate off the shelf and are replaced by new organic varieties, there've been a number of out-of-stock situations and shelf label changes. As customers work to replenish their selves, our shipments of gourmet items were strong toward the end of the third quarter and we expect this to bleed [ph] through stronger in retail consumption data for the fourth quarter.
For those customers who have completed the resets to organic gourmet, we're seeing significant sales lift and we expect most of our customers to have these conversions complete before the holiday period begins later this fall. In addition, with this move to organic, we've been able to increase our distribution of gourmet items with 4 of our top 10 retailers.
Looking ahead to the fourth quarter, we're excited about this year's holiday period in the U.S. We are reminding consumers to flavor these important meals with the pure flavors of the holiday. During high consumption periods, we're driving brand loyalty through television, digital and in-store communications and featuring some of our latest core product innovation such as roasted ground cinnamon and ginger bread spice. 
As part of our fourth quarter communication plan, we're reactivating our highly successful purity campaign. This campaign has been particularly effective with millennial consumers. We measured a 2 percentage point increase millennial household penetration for McCormick spices and seasonings when we introduced our Purity message. In addition, the Purity TV and digital messaging lifted millennials purchase intent for McCormick brand by 15 percentage points. This is driving a strong retail sales response with a 9% increase in our spices and seasonings during a 7-week on-air period. 
Across all of our markets, and both of our segments, our leaders and employees throughout McCormick are driving toward a solid finish and great fiscal year results. McCormick is uniquely positioned as a global leader in flavor, a category that is on-trend with today's consumer and healthy eating. We're driving strong momentum with our strategies to grow sales, balanced with our CCI program and other efforts to build fuel for growth and higher margins. 
I'd like to thank you for your attention and it's not my pleasure to turn over to Mike. Mike?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lawrence, and good morning, everyone. As Lawrence indicated, our third quarter results continued the strong performance we achieved in the first half. I'll provide some added perspective on the financial results and then discuss the details of
componenttext:
Thank you, Lawrence, and good morning, everyone. As Lawrence indicated, our third quarter results continued the strong performance we achieved in the first half. I'll provide some added perspective on the financial results and then discuss the details of our latest 2016 financial outlook. 
On a constant currency basis, we grew sales 6%. Acquisitions, higher volume and product mix and pricing, taken in response to higher material costs, each contributed to the increase as seen on Slide 12. Both our consumer and industrial segments delivered solid top line growth, with increases in each of our 3 regions. 
On Slide 13, consumer segment sales in the Americas rose 8% in constant currency with 3 percentage points of the increase from acquisitions, both Stubb's and Gourmet Garden. The balance of sales growth this period was in the U.S. and led by McCormick and Lawry's brand spices and seasonings, veterans brand items and Kitchen Basics products. 
These sales increases were offset in part by a slight decline in our sales of private label and economy brands. 
EMEA consumer segment sales rose 1% in constant currency. We've continued to drive sales growth in Poland and Russia that includes the benefit of new distribution. And we delivered another strong sales quarter, along with category share gains in France with new products and brand marketing. These gains were offset in part by weakness in the U.K. where a number of food companies have been challenged by a difficult retail environment. 
We grew consumer sales in the Asia/Pacific region 11% in constant currency. Sales from Gourmet Garden added 7 percentage points of this growth. In China, we returned to a strong sales increase this quarter, following some moderation in the second quarter that related to a successful SAP implementation in our Wuhan facility. Third quarter sales in China were mainly driven by promotional activity and pricing. Year-to-date, our consumer sales in China are up 9% on constant currency basis. 
A decline in India lowered our third quarter sales in this region by 6 percentage points due to a decision a year ago to discontinue certain low-margin products. 
For the consumer segment in total, we grew adjusted operating income 11% to $127 million. In constant currency, adjusted operating income rose 12% from a year-ago period. The impact of sales growth and the cost-savings more than offset higher material costs and our investments in growth, including higher brand marketing. 
Turning to our industrial segment in Slide 17, we had excellent results this quarter in both sales and profit. We grew industrial sales in the Americas 4% in constant currency. This strong performance was driven by sales of branded food service products in the U.S. where we've gained share with a leading customer. Also, in the U.S., we've been winning business with several new restaurant customers, although demand from some of the quick service restaurants remains weak. And in Latin America, we're growing sales of snack seasonings and other products supplied from our operation in Mexico. 
In Canada, we took pricing to pass-through higher material costs that include the impact of currency but this was offset by weaker volume for industrial products in that market. 
We grew industrial sales in EMEA 5% in constant currency versus the third quarter of 2015. We had solid sales growth of branded food service products and customized flavored solutions. 
Industrial segment sales in the Asia/Pacific region were up 3% in constant currency. We had strong growth from our operations in Australia and Southeast Asia, driven in part by new product wins and promotional activity by our quick service restaurant customers. 
In China, as we indicated last quarter, a large customer is diversifying their supply chain by adding a second supplier for some core items that McCormick supplies. 
Adjusted operating income for the industrial segment ended the quarter up 14% at $45 million. In constant currency, the growth was 23%, driven by higher sales, our cost savings and more favorable business mix, offset in part by higher material cost and increases in brand marketing.
For those of you to follow as closely know that the industrial segment tends to have some quarter-to-quarter profit volatility, largely due to customer ability, including new product launches, limited-time offers and other promotions. Following an exceptionally strong third quarter, we are projecting adjusted operating income growth for this segment to slow in the fourth quarter. For the fiscal year, we expect both an increase in adjusted operating income and improve margins versus 2015. 
Across both segments, adjusted operating income, which excludes special charges rose 12% in the third quarter from a year-ago period. And excluding the impact of unfavorable currency, we grew adjusted operating income by 15%. Year-to-date, the increase in adjusted operating income in constant currency is 11%. 
We increased gross profit margin 180 basis points year-on-year to 41.6% in the third quarter. This improvement was a result of cost savings from our CCI and streamlining actions, favorable mix and pricing actions taken to offset higher costs. Given the rise in certain materials as Lawrence described, we still expect to increase gross margin in the fourth quarter but the increase is likely to be below 100 basis points. 
Our selling, general and administrative expense as a percentage of net sales was up year-on-year by 20 basis points from the third quarter of 2015, mainly due to the increase in brand marketing. 
The tax rate on a GAAP basis this quarter was 22.3%, below both the prior year rate and our previous guidance for the second half, mainly due to discrete tax items. At this time, we expected tax rate of 28% to 29% in the fourth quarter and a fiscal year 2016 tax rate to 25% to 26%.
The income from unconsolidated operations was down this quarter by $2 million. As a reminder, income from unconsolidated operations in the third quarter 2015 had a $2 million favorable impact from special charges due to the minority interest in our payment joint venture in India. Currency also had an unfavorable impact on year-ago comparison. However, we had good underlying performance. Our largest joint venture, McCormick de Mexico, has grown year-to-date sales at a high single-digit rate in local currency. We anticipated greater impact from unfavorable currency and have increased our expected decline in income from unconsolidated operations to about 15% from approximately 10%. 
At the bottom line, third quarter 2016 adjusted earnings per share was $1.03. This was an $0.18 increase from a year-ago period as a result of higher adjusted operating income, a favorable tax rate and lower shares outstanding. As a reminder, this year-to-year comparison includes the unfavorable impact from currency on both consolidated and unconsolidated income. 
On Slide 26, we've summarized highlights for cash flow and the quarter end balance sheet. Through the first 3 quarters of 2016, cash flow from operations was $322 million, up slightly from the year-ago period. The impact of higher net income was offset in part by pension contribution, timing of tax payments and an increase in trade receivables this period. For the third quarter, our cash and conversion cycle was down from the year-ago period and we are putting programs in place, such as extended payment terms with our suppliers to achieve further reductions. 
We still expect capital expenditures of $150 million to $160 million. Much of this is in support of our growth with major construction in both Shanghai and Dubai. In August, we approved future capital investments in Southeast Asia to support our growth with the new manufacturing facility in Thailand and a new and advanced technical innovation center in Singapore. 
We're also returning a portion of cash to our shareholders and through the 3 quarters, used $343 million for dividends and share repurchases. At the end of the third quarter, $391 million remained on the current $600 million share repurchase authorization. Note that we now expect to reduce shares outstanding by 1% from fiscal year 2015. This is below our initial projection of 2% and is due to the curtailment of our repurchases related to acquisition activity in 2016. 
In summary, 2016 is expected to be another year of strong cash flow, providing the funds for continued investment and acquisitions and other growth strategies. Our debt leverage is low, and we are well positioned to finance these investment. 
Let's move now to our financial guidance. We continue to expect strong growth for fiscal year 2016 and have updated several projections based on our third quarter results and latest outlook for the fourth quarter. At the top line, we expect to grow sales approximately 3% on a reported basis and approximately 6% in constant currency. This is at the upper end of our previous range and implies a fourth quarter increase of approximately 6% on a constant currency basis. We expect to grow adjusted operating income approximately 7% from $614 million in 2015. In constant currency, our estimated rate of growth is 10%, which is at the midpoint of the previous range. 
Our guidance for cost savings remains $100 million to $110 million, and our current estimate for increased brand marketing is around $15 million, reflecting the spending efficiencies that Lawrence noted. As also discussed, we're increasing our guidance range for adjusted earnings per share to $3.75 to $3.79. Our previous guidance for adjusted EPS with the upper end of $3.68 to $3.75. This increase reflects the favorable third quarter results, partially offset by the effective currency on our income from unconsolidated operations, a lower reduction in shares outstanding and the rise of vanilla and garlic. Excluding the estimated 4 percentage point impact of unfavorable currency rates, this range is an increase of 12% to 13% from adjusted earnings per share of $3.48 in 2015. 
Based on this fiscal year 2016 range, we're projecting adjusted EPS for the fourth quarter of $1.24 to $1.28. This is an increase of 5% to 8% from adjusted EPS of $1.18 in the fourth quarter of 2015. 
To summarize, our projected fiscal year 2016 constant currency growth rates for sales, adjusted operating income and adjusted earnings per share are at or above our long-term objectives for the business. We look forward to reporting our final results to you in January. 
That completes my remarks. I'm going to turn it back over to Lawrence.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. As we move to your question, let me leave you with our key takeaways for the quarter. First, we had great results. In constant currency, we grew sales 6% with growth in both segments in each region and adjusted operating income was up 15%. W
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. As we move to your question, let me leave you with our key takeaways for the quarter. First, we had great results. In constant currency, we grew sales 6% with growth in both segments in each region and adjusted operating income was up 15%. We're executing on an effective strategy to drive sales and lower costs. Our CCI program is driving higher margins and profit and generating fuel for growth. And based on our year-to-date results and business momentum, we expect 2016 to be a record year for McCormick. 
So operator, let's take the first question.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citigroup.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from the line of David Driscoll with Citigroup.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2 questions I was hoping to ask. The first question is I just like to hear your thoughts on U.S. food trends and just kind of what you're seeing from the consumer, specifically it's been pretty strong growth within the spice category but yet the ove
componenttext: I had 2 questions I was hoping to ask. The first question is I just like to hear your thoughts on U.S. food trends and just kind of what you're seeing from the consumer, specifically it's been pretty strong growth within the spice category but yet the overall grocery stores had been deflationary. I just like to hear your thoughts about kind of the differential between these 2 and does it have any implications to your category going forward? And then a follow, if I may.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, David. I think that the food generally still continues to be relatively flat and the spice category, herbs and spices, is one of the strongest categories in the store. If you look at a heat map for the entire store, you would see that the he
componenttext: Well, thanks, David. I think that the food generally still continues to be relatively flat and the spice category, herbs and spices, is one of the strongest categories in the store. If you look at a heat map for the entire store, you would see that the herbs and spice category is about the hottest spot in the store.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I totally understand that. Do you think that there's anything to be worried about in terms of the deflation that we see more broadly in the store versus this exceptional growth? Or, in fact, is lower prices in the meat category maybe a positive linka
componenttext: Yes, I totally understand that. Do you think that there's anything to be worried about in terms of the deflation that we see more broadly in the store versus this exceptional growth? Or, in fact, is lower prices in the meat category maybe a positive linkage to what's going on in spices, that's really what I'm trying to drive at.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we just see the spice category being driven by a number of long-term trends, David. Yes, there's increased interest in cooking from scratch as millennials come to be a larger, larger part of the shopping universe. We've talked about this a couple of
componenttext: Yes, we just see the spice category being driven by a number of long-term trends, David. Yes, there's increased interest in cooking from scratch as millennials come to be a larger, larger part of the shopping universe. We've talked about this a couple of times. And we just think that's a real advantage for our core category. I'm not so sure that I can speak to a change in the trend for the whole center of the store. There does seem to be a shift away from more prepared foods and a move towards closer to fresh, more scratch-type foods I think that bodes well for the perimeter of the store and for companies that have businesses that involves scratch cooking and again, I think that that's a positive for our category. There's also a trend towards greater interest in health and wellness and healthier eating and again I think that's supportive of the urban spice category, particularly in the U.S. where we -- where herbs and spices are in the Dietary Guidelines for Americans really for the first time ever as a strategy for reducing things like added salt, added sugar in foods.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one fast follow-up...
componenttext: Just one fast follow-up...

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see this also on the industrial side of our business, I almost left that out. Many of our industrial customers are working with us to change the formulations of their products to make them more natural, to take out things that sound artificial, to make
componenttext: We see this also on the industrial side of our business, I almost left that out. Many of our industrial customers are working with us to change the formulations of their products to make them more natural, to take out things that sound artificial, to make them sound fresher and less processed.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick follow-up on inflation and pricing. I believe that you said, but I just want to confirm, that you've had a tremendous period here where you've actually had price increases on the portfolio, yet I believe it's been net deflation where you had low s
componenttext: A quick follow-up on inflation and pricing. I believe that you said, but I just want to confirm, that you've had a tremendous period here where you've actually had price increases on the portfolio, yet I believe it's been net deflation where you had low single-digit raw material inflation but this incredible CCI program, so on balance, net deflation. But it sounds like in your script, you're telling us that going forward it's not going to be as good, the inflation is really going to pick up, as I think you call that a couple of particular items but it sounded like there was a real material change here in the trajectory of inflation. Is that correct and is that the message?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's been a lot of volatility in raw materials over the last couple of years. We've had to deal with a long and sustained increase in the cost of one of our iconic raw materials, in particular, that being pepper. We did this year experienced low
componenttext: Well, there's been a lot of volatility in raw materials over the last couple of years. We've had to deal with a long and sustained increase in the cost of one of our iconic raw materials, in particular, that being pepper. We did this year experienced low single-digit inflation so I wouldn't say that there was deflation in our cost. CCI doesn't just go to the cost of the raw material inputs but looks at every line of the P&L. A portion of that CCI was in our fixed cost structure and SG&A and so on. We do see a higher rate of inflation for next year, but we're really not ready to give guidance on 2017 just yet. We are seeing cost increases that are quite well publicized in a couple of key raw materials, vanilla and garlic. But we also anticipate that we are going to be able to take pricing actions that will  -- are between pricing actions and CCI we'll be able to mitigate those costs. What we're really talking about in the fourth quarter is that some of the pricing actions that we took were against raw material cost increases that occurred in the market, but had some strategic positions. And so as the cost of those materials as they flow through begin to catch up with the price increases that margin improvement that we've been experiencing will begin to narrow. Mike, do you want to comment on?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've seen this trend coming and we've taken pricing actions for things like vanilla this year in the U.S. a couple of times. In China we're taking the garlic actions right now. So we've been ahead of the curve here and we're monitoring very closely.
componenttext: Yes, we've seen this trend coming and we've taken pricing actions for things like vanilla this year in the U.S. a couple of times. In China we're taking the garlic actions right now. So we've been ahead of the curve here and we're monitoring very closely. But through pricing and CCI upping the level there, we feel comfortable we'll cover the costs going into next year. We'll provide market in our January earnings call.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Goldman with JPMorgan.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one follow-up as you guys think about the gross margin growth into 4Q, I think you talked about it decelerating, you mentioned garlic and vanilla. Are there any other headwinds we should be thinking about as we model the fourth quarter's gross margin
componenttext: Just one follow-up as you guys think about the gross margin growth into 4Q, I think you talked about it decelerating, you mentioned garlic and vanilla. Are there any other headwinds we should be thinking about as we model the fourth quarter's gross margin? Or is it really that that you're focus on any what is the focus on as we think about those levels?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, in terms of gross margin, those are the really, I'd say, those are the right things to be focused on. I want to be clear that we're talking about lower rate of margin improvement, so we're not talking about a margin decline. The other thing though i
componenttext: Well, in terms of gross margin, those are the really, I'd say, those are the right things to be focused on. I want to be clear that we're talking about lower rate of margin improvement, so we're not talking about a margin decline. The other thing though is I read through to EPS, that's actually the minority of the kind of what I'd call, the gap, between our beat in third quarter and the amount that we're raising our guidance by. The larger impact items is that we are expecting more FX impact, particularly on our -- on our JV income, that's below the operating profit line. It's comes through on the unconsolidated line. A big part of that JV income is from a joint venture in Mexico. We've seen a substantial softening in the peso, they're having great result. The translations of those great results by back into U.S. dollars is less than we had anticipated when we had our second -- when we had our last call. The other major factor is just a lower-rate of share repurchase. As you know, we curtail our share repurchases when we have an acquisition between actually completed acquisition activity and for activity around deals that we did not complete, there was a curtailment of share repurchase and we end up it looks like our share repurchase are going to be closer to 1% than 2%. And that's a substantial factor also. Mike, do you want to...

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the other factor, we talked about the material cost rising during the year and the industrial business had a great third quarter, real good mix, we had strong branded food service business, which is high margin for us. And yes, the timing of
componenttext: Yes, I think the other factor, we talked about the material cost rising during the year and the industrial business had a great third quarter, real good mix, we had strong branded food service business, which is high margin for us. And yes, the timing of some those promotions and some of our customers were basically the same as the fourth quarter. For the full year, we're very happy with the performance, but I wouldn't expect them to grow at the 23% adjusted operating income again in that fourth quarter.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. One quick follow up for me, if I can. There was some comment I meet misheard I'm really asking sort of a clarification about their relationship with raw materials savings in CCI. Could you repeat that, that because I was hearing it b
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. One quick follow up for me, if I can. There was some comment I meet misheard I'm really asking sort of a clarification about their relationship with raw materials savings in CCI. Could you repeat that, that because I was hearing it but I wasn't quite sure what you were saying about the raw materials savings for included in how you calculate CCI and so forth, that would be helpful?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Definitely. When we renegotiate with vendors or have raw materials savings, they are included in CCI.
componenttext: Definitely. When we renegotiate with vendors or have raw materials savings, they are included in CCI.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: But [indiscernible] garlic prices go up or down, you're talking about more actives...
componenttext: But [indiscernible] garlic prices go up or down, you're talking about more actives...

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: More active reformulations, yes, vendor consolidation, things like that, market movement does [indiscernible] count.
componenttext: More active reformulations, yes, vendor consolidation, things like that, market movement does [indiscernible] count.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is coming from the line of Robert Moskow with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is coming from the line of Robert Moskow with Credit Suisse.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Lawrence, I think you said that your advertising efficiencies are helping you save about $5 million versus your prior expectations. And it sounds like you're dropping it to the bottom line, but you're also keeping your operating income guidance for the ye
componenttext: Lawrence, I think you said that your advertising efficiencies are helping you save about $5 million versus your prior expectations. And it sounds like you're dropping it to the bottom line, but you're also keeping your operating income guidance for the year unchanged as far as I can tell. So is the $5 million in savings kind of offsetting some of this narrower gross margin trend that you're talking about in fourth quarter, owing to costs and I think you also said timing of purchases of customers?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. The change in the guidance on advertising really relates to being more efficient with digital and more efficient with our -- the nonworking portion of advertising. We're running all the programs that we intended to. We, frankly, to spend the $5 millio
componenttext: No. The change in the guidance on advertising really relates to being more efficient with digital and more efficient with our -- the nonworking portion of advertising. We're running all the programs that we intended to. We, frankly, to spend the $5 million, we'd have to waste it. A portion of that, of the change in outlook actually's already captured in Q3. And so this is a change in guidance for the full year and not really specific to the fourth quarter.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I think maybe my question then is that the $5 million benefit in third quarter, you could have taken it to the year and raised your op income guidance for the year, but instead fourth quarter is going to be a little bit lower than that at leas
componenttext: Okay. Well, I think maybe my question then is that the $5 million benefit in third quarter, you could have taken it to the year and raised your op income guidance for the year, but instead fourth quarter is going to be a little bit lower than that at least, what I thought, well, what I had modeled. So is this a comment about a more challenging gross margin environment in the fourth quarter than you thought? Or maybe there's potential for upside in 4Q?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, again, another point to the fourth quarter, I know you're talking about operating income specifically, I'm thinking about the whole P&L all the way down. But the 3 headwinds that we talked about, the FX impact, the lower share repurchases, summarized
componenttext: No, again, another point to the fourth quarter, I know you're talking about operating income specifically, I'm thinking about the whole P&L all the way down. But the 3 headwinds that we talked about, the FX impact, the lower share repurchases, summarized in raw material costs are really the factors that we want to overcome. I also got to say that we are a bit conservative when we look at guidance, as we get to fourth quarter because it's our largest quarter, October and November are our highest shipping months. One big order from one customer or 1-odd shipping day in the last week of the year can swing the number of it. And so we tend to be careful in the guidance that we give that can be interpreted that's specific to fourth quarter.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and to put in perspective, too, our first half of the year, our adjusted operating income was up between 5% to 6%. We had a really good third quarter at 12% for a variety of reasons. And fourth quarter is about 1/3 of our earnings per share, so it's
componenttext: Yes, and to put in perspective, too, our first half of the year, our adjusted operating income was up between 5% to 6%. We had a really good third quarter at 12% for a variety of reasons. And fourth quarter is about 1/3 of our earnings per share, so it's a big quarter for us. So there's a lot of moving parts as Lawrence said.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one more question. You have rising cost garlic and vanilla, I was a little unclear, are you considering taking -- you're going to take more pricing, it sounded like you were proactive and already taking some pricing. When will U.S. customers be
componenttext: Okay. Just one more question. You have rising cost garlic and vanilla, I was a little unclear, are you considering taking -- you're going to take more pricing, it sounded like you were proactive and already taking some pricing. When will U.S. customers be notified of the pricing? And how do you think the category will respond? You had issues with private label or just really more like lower costs brands a couple of years ago. Do you expect everyone else to follow?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't want to get too specific about the exact timing of the pricing actions, but I'm -- I know that we will be taking pricing action. We've moved on vanilla twice already this year and expect that, that will be one of the areas where we go up. For
componenttext: Yes, I don't want to get too specific about the exact timing of the pricing actions, but I'm -- I know that we will be taking pricing action. We've moved on vanilla twice already this year and expect that, that will be one of the areas where we go up. For vanilla, in particular, is in a situation where there's a worldwide shortage. We don't believe that any competitor is advantage versus McCormick in their raw -- in that particular commodity. And indeed, we believe that we're actually in an advantage supply position compared to some of our competitors. We've been approached by customers of competitors who are experiencing defaults and are having difficulty getting vanilla at any price. The raw material and the shortage of that raw material is going to dictate the higher price across the whole market and we're confident that we won't be moving along. The other thing, too, is this category management tools we've invested in over to cut years, shown we took the pricing action earlier in the U.S., our volume rate of share gain and volume that was positive, so we grew volume while taking a price increase. So we're doing much smarter than we used to. So we feel we need to take pricing again, will do that with a minimal impact to volume.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Mario Contreras with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Mario Contreras with Deutsche Bank.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to follow up on the U.S. business. You mentioned that at least in terms of the scanner data, we're seeing market share down. You attributed most of that to the shift to gourmet organic product line. If we set that aside, can you comment on how
componenttext: So I wanted to follow up on the U.S. business. You mentioned that at least in terms of the scanner data, we're seeing market share down. You attributed most of that to the shift to gourmet organic product line. If we set that aside, can you comment on how some of your other key product lines were performing in terms of market share?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if we took that aside, we'd essentially be flat on market share. Really, it's the disruption at the shelf due to the transition from the kind of the conventional spices that were in gourmet to the new organic spices that really cost -- that disrupti
componenttext: Well, if we took that aside, we'd essentially be flat on market share. Really, it's the disruption at the shelf due to the transition from the kind of the conventional spices that were in gourmet to the new organic spices that really cost -- that disruption really accounted for nearly all of the share gap. What else can I say about that. Really, I mean, I mean that's really the whole story there, Mario. We're pretty pleased with our progress our overall. And the gourmet was the one thing. I should add that it wasn't really a surprise. We had our call back in the -- last call back in June, we were in the middle of it. We knew what was happening and we said on the call that was this was going to happen and there would be some disruption at the shelf. I'm pretty encouraged that will have worked pretty optimistic that we'll have completely worked through it by the time that the real holiday season starts. The shipments that we experienced on gourmet don't really line up with the consumption. They were very strong at the end of the quarter as our customers were restocking their shelves. So I'm pretty, pretty encouraged about that. But again, if I just go back to your original question, the scanner data, it's really a story about gourmet.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks for that color. One other question if I could shift to China on the industrial business. You've mentioned recently that there was a partial loss from a customer that was diversifying. Has there been any progress in terms of sourcing that busi
componenttext: Okay, thanks for that color. One other question if I could shift to China on the industrial business. You've mentioned recently that there was a partial loss from a customer that was diversifying. Has there been any progress in terms of sourcing that business to other customers or finding some way to offset some of the deleverage that might have happened there?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly have a broad customer base in China and we continue to work to build our business with local Chinese based customers, both on the restaurant food service side and on the consumer food manufacturer. But this is a very large customer. And
componenttext: Well, we certainly have a broad customer base in China and we continue to work to build our business with local Chinese based customers, both on the restaurant food service side and on the consumer food manufacturer. But this is a very large customer. And so their diversification of their supply base is going to have an impact on our business. That is not something that just can't be immediately made up. I expect that we'll grow into it. But this customer had a problem with a supplier that put them in a bad business position and they've made a strategic decision that they're not going to be sole-sourced on anything. And the products that we supply, we were very close to the exclusive supplier. So as they -- as that customer diversifies it supplier base, it does have an impact on us as well due to their strategy.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Lubi [ph] filling in for Akshay. So you mentioned in your press release that the -- your Kohinoor business in India saw better results this quarter versus last year. I'm just wondering if you can provide a bit more color on a sort of what's drivin
componenttext: This is Lubi [ph] filling in for Akshay. So you mentioned in your press release that the -- your Kohinoor business in India saw better results this quarter versus last year. I'm just wondering if you can provide a bit more color on a sort of what's driving that and how you expect trends in that business to develop over the course of the near future?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'm just going to say a few words about it. Last year, we exited a portion of the business that was very low margin and frankly, executionally complicated. And so we were able to simplify the business, improve the margin and left us with the busines
componenttext: Sure, I'm just going to say a few words about it. Last year, we exited a portion of the business that was very low margin and frankly, executionally complicated. And so we were able to simplify the business, improve the margin and left us with the business that was smaller than it was. I think what's the nature of the comments in the script were. We are not going to elaborate a lot on Kohinoor just because it is so small relative to the rest of our business. The Kohinoor business is less than 1%, it's actually less than -- it's approximately 0.5% of our business. And so we don't -- we're not going -- we just not going to get too specific comment on a business unit that size.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: But we have [indiscernible] our strategy there longer term is to roll out more spices and seasonings and recipe mixes and that's still on track as we talked about on the past. So long term, this is a great market for us.
componenttext: But we have [indiscernible] our strategy there longer term is to roll out more spices and seasonings and recipe mixes and that's still on track as we talked about on the past. So long term, this is a great market for us.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is just 1 of 3 businesses that we have in India. The other 2 are on the unconsolidated line, they're nonconsolidated joint ventures.
componenttext: And this is just 1 of 3 businesses that we have in India. The other 2 are on the unconsolidated line, they're nonconsolidated joint ventures.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you guys are expecting a near-term slowdown in the rate of margin improvement. And I'm assuming that, that bleeds into fiscal '17 as well. I know you're not providing guidance for
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you guys are expecting a near-term slowdown in the rate of margin improvement. And I'm assuming that, that bleeds into fiscal '17 as well. I know you're not providing guidance for fiscal '17 yet, but are there any other sort of high-level puts and takes that we should be thinking about that might impact earnings growth for the next year?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're really going to give some pretty robust earnings guidance for 2017 on our January call as we always do. We're in the middle of putting together budgets right now. So any guidance that we could give would -- it'd probably incomplete and too soon. Yes
componenttext: We're really going to give some pretty robust earnings guidance for 2017 on our January call as we always do. We're in the middle of putting together budgets right now. So any guidance that we could give would -- it'd probably incomplete and too soon. Yes, we are giving some of visibility that we're experiencing an increase in the commodity costs on those 2 particular commodity and that we expect our pricing actions to cover that increase. But I don't think we're ready to give guidance on margins, other than to the extent that we're talking about Q4 right now.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from the line of Andrew Lazar with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The next question comes from the line of Andrew Lazar with Barclays.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to make sure I understand what I should expect around the U.S. consumer business in the fourth quarter. Is it that you incremental visible now that you've got a lot of this shelf reset worked its way through. Is it that you have visibility to
componenttext: I just want to make sure I understand what I should expect around the U.S. consumer business in the fourth quarter. Is it that you incremental visible now that you've got a lot of this shelf reset worked its way through. Is it that you have visibility to an acceleration in consumption in the fourth quarter? Or is it that the over shipment in 3Q could result in a bit of understatement in the fiscal fourth quarter?

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, that over shipment that you just referred to is just on gourmet. It was really a restocking. It's actually making an under shipment in Q2 and Q3. When we spoke about this at the end of Q2, Andrew, I think we said that we had actu
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, that over shipment that you just referred to is just on gourmet. It was really a restocking. It's actually making an under shipment in Q2 and Q3. When we spoke about this at the end of Q2, Andrew, I think we said that we had actually restrained our shipments on gourmet at the end of Q2 to manage the transition. We didn't want to get a lot of returns of the old product as we went through the transition. So we were rationing it out a bit. And then in Q3, there's some disruption of the shelf and really just a refilling of the shelves. And so, no, I don't expect the slowdown. Actually, we're encouraged by the strength of our holiday program in the U.S. business as we look to into the holiday season. We're actually pretty optimistic that we're going to have both strong shipments and strong consumption. We're back on air with the purity campaign, we've got a tremendous lift from that campaign when we ran that earlier this year. So our holiday advertising will include Purity. When we ran that purity campaign, we not only got an immediate lift from it but also increased our penetration with minimally also, which builds the franchise for the long term. I think that we're feeling pretty good about Q4 in the U.S.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, that's helpful clarification. Just one last one just more to check my memory. I could remember this incorrectly but I remember years ago when there was a vanilla issue I think coming out of Madagascar, there might have been some effort to try and e
componenttext: Great, that's helpful clarification. Just one last one just more to check my memory. I could remember this incorrectly but I remember years ago when there was a vanilla issue I think coming out of Madagascar, there might have been some effort to try and expand or diversify the sourcing of vanilla into some other markets and growing regions. I know it's kind of hard to do, it takes time for that to develop. But whether it be areas like in Vietnam and others, I guess whatever became of that? Is it still happening but it's just not big enough to really make up the difference in terms of Madagascar sourcing or it's more out of curiosity on my part.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's the advantage of having a long memory there, Andrew. We did have a vanilla shortage back in 2003, '04, '05. And that all -- that's [indiscernible] into the company, so some of this -- what happened then is old [indiscernible] for me. But subsequent
componenttext: That's the advantage of having a long memory there, Andrew. We did have a vanilla shortage back in 2003, '04, '05. And that all -- that's [indiscernible] into the company, so some of this -- what happened then is old [indiscernible] for me. But subsequently, there was quite a big market decline and many of those sources dried up due to market pricing. We are, ourselves, working actively to develop the growth of vanilla in a number of regions of the world and including a pilot operation that we have to grow our own. But those are efforts that will take a little bit of time to bring on stream. And right now, 85% of the world's vanilla comes from medical NASCAR and that's where they shortages. A lot of the changes, not so much around supply, but around demand consumers want to move to a more natural flavors, there's a shift in market demand away from artificial vanilla and Ventolin [ph] to being able to label the product straight up vanilla or vanilla beans. So we do have an effort underway to develop those alternate sources. Again, I'll just emphasize that we believe that nobody has an advantage to position right now in the market versus us. And we know just from the customer inquiries that we're getting that in fact, we probably have an advantage position versus a number of our competitors.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this time, I'll turn the floor back to Lawrence Kurzius for closing remarks.
componenttext: At this time, I'll turn the floor back to Lawrence Kurzius for closing remarks.

headline: McCormick & Company, Incorporated, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Sep 30, 2016

componenttext: Well, I'd like to thank everyone for your questions and for participating in today's call. For our growth strategies and our people, our experienced leaders and engaged employees, for driving strong performance at McCormick, for executing on a strategy designed to build long-term value for our shareholders and we look forward to reporting to you on our continued progress.
